awd_titl_txt: RAISE-TAQS: Quantum Advantage of Broadband Entangled Photon Pairs in Spectroscopy and Metrology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award in the Research Advanced by Interdisciplinary Science and Engineering (RAISE) on Transformational Advances in Quantum Systems (TAQS) program supports collaborative work by Professors Michael Raymer, Andrew Marcus and Brian Smith at the University of Oregon to demonstrate experimentally improved performance in the sensing of remote objects and the spectroscopy of electronically coupled molecules using quantum mechanical states of light. Advancements in nonlinear optical spectroscopy and metrology that rely on intrinsically quantum mechanical effects are of broad scientific interest to the chemistry, physics and engineering communities. The methods and research so developed will create new opportunities that may be utilized in the expanding interdisciplinary field of quantum information science. The supported research will facilitate the dissemination of results at international meetings and workshops, and the tools developed will be made readily available to the scientific community. The three PIs will collaborate on all aspects of the proposed work, and will co-advise the PhD students working on the projects. The students involved will thus enjoy a unique and broad exposure to research training that spans quantum optics, ultrafast molecular spectroscopy, and biophysics.

An interdisciplinary team spanning chemistry, physics, and engineering in the Oregon Center for Optical, Molecular, and Quantum Science, will carry out experiments to demonstrate that Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen (EPR)-like entanglement of photons in the time-frequency domain can provide a significant quantum advantage in spectroscopy and metrology. Time-frequency entangled photon pairs (EPP) are tightly correlated in time while being anti-correlated in frequency, such that the sum of the energies of the photon pair is sharply defined. Such quantum states of light offer the ability to circumvent classical Fourier time-bandwidth limits when employing photon coincidence events, either in detection, as in standard quantum optics, or in two-photon excitation of molecular complexes, as in nonlinear spectroscopy. The research will investigate potential quantum advantages in the context of four related optical schemes in metrology and nonlinear spectroscopy: 1) Quantum illumination (sensing of an object's presence or absence); 2) Multi-parameter estimation of complementary parameters (e.g., estimating the distance and velocity of a reflecting object); 3) Two-photon interferometric nonlinear spectroscopy; and 4) Entangled photon-pair 2D fluorescence spectroscopy. The commonality that unifies the four schemes is the use of broad-band (multi-spectral-mode), time-frequency EPP produced by spontaneous parametric down-conversion (SPDC), coupled with interferometer configurations that exploit quantum interference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The idea of quantum-enabled metrology (the quantitative measurement of physical properties) in a key concept in the rapidly growing research area of quantum information science and technology (QIST). There is growing recognition in the chemistry and biochemistry communities that quantum light can offer new enhancements in optical and near-infrared spectroscopy, potentially bringing new capabilities to biological studies, including imaging and function. By ‘quantum light’ we mean light that is engineered to have properties unique to quantum physics, such as quantum state entanglement, which is not available from conventional light sources such as lasers or lamps. Our project has been one of the leaders in bringing forward the ideas of quantum-enhanced spectroscopy. In this project, we developed detailed theoretical and experimental methods to define and to study the issues involved and discovered practical limits to the efficiency of such techniques in important cases.

In progress towards this goal, we pursued three closely related subprojects, unified by the working relationship between the three PIs and their groups at the University of Oregon:

 

Project 1. Experiments using broadband entangled photon pairs (EPP) to excite two-photon absorption in a molecular sample.

An important development is the potential employment of time-frequency-entangled photon pairs (TF-EPP) for enhancing nonlinear spectroscopy of microscopy of molecular samples. TF-EPP are a category of nonclassical light, in which pairs of photons arrive at the molecule at nearly the same time while having frequencies correlated such that the sum of the two photons’ energies is sharply defined. These quantum attributes can greatly enhance the rate at which such entangled photons can be absorbed in a process known as two-photon absorption. If realizable, such a method would improve spectroscopy and microscopy by allowing a lower power of light to interact with the sample, ideally enabling sensitive studies of the sample without damaging it.

Unfortunately, we found that typical molecular samples did not yield any measurable two-photon-absorption signal when using TF-EPP. The lack of signal led us to develop a detailed theoretical model, which makes clear that two-photon-absorption signals, while theoretically nonzero, are too small to detect in practical experiments. The theory results are consistent with the unobservability of such signals, even when using state-of-the-art detection methods as used in our experiments.

The results are important for the world-wide science community that is considering such schemes and techniques.

 

Project 2. Classical ultrafast laser spectroscopy of the same samples mentioned above, using techniques developed previously at University of Oregon with the addition of novel photon-counting methods developed under the current project.

The goal of this subproject was to enable ultrafast (sub-picosecond Fourier transform) spectroscopy on molecular samples under ultra-low-light conditions, as is necessary to perform molecular spectroscopy experiments using entangled photon pairs (EPP). For this purpose, we developed a novel photon-counting method for phase-sensitive single-photon detection, which we named phase-tagged photon counting (PTPC). We have applied the PTPC method to perform novel studies on molecular systems including two-photon excitation two-dimensional fluorescence spectroscopy and polarization-sweep single-molecule fluorescence spectroscopy.

Although our plans to investigate molecular samples using EPP spectroscopy were not realized due to the absence of detectable signal (as outlined in Project 1), we were able to implement the phase-tagged photon counting (PTPC) scheme that we developed for low signal (photon counting) detection to accomplish these two novel related studies.

 

Project 3. All-optical experiments studying nonlinear-optical two-photon sum-frequency conversion of EPP, which mirrors theoretically the two-photon absorption in a molecular sample.

Entangled photon pairs (EPP) that exhibit spectral-temporal correlations are essential tools for many proposed quantum applications, particularly the quantum-enhanced spectroscopy being studied within this project. Thus, it is important to be able to characterize EPP experimentally and theoretically. Much of the work to date has relied on spontaneous parametric down conversion (SPDC) as a source of EPP. SPDC can be considered as the probabilistic splitting of a single input photon (from a laser) into two output photons with energies that sum to that of the input photon. Conversely, sum-frequency generation (SFG) implements the reverse process of combining two input photons into a single output photon. We have analyzed theoretically how mode-resolved measurements performed on the photons produced in the SFG process realizes a (projective) quantum measurement of the input two-photon state that is entangled. The two-photon measurements can be viewed as being closely related to the two-photon states produced by the time-reversed SPDC process.

In addition to the SFG work, we successfully explored the ability to generate spectrally entangled photon pairs in a ‘heralded’ fashion, that is having knowledge of when the source produces EPP. The ability to transfer (swap) entanglement between systems is an important protocol in quantum information science. We carried out an experiment demonstrating entanglement swapping from two independent multimode time-frequency entangled sources, resulting in multiple heralded entangled states.
